clinically indicated, a repeat transthoracic study by a
son[**Name (NI) 930**] with possible contrast administration for
endocardial definition may be helpful.


Brief Hospital Course:
46 yo M with HCV, HTN, EtOH abuse, dilated alcoholic CMY (EF
25%), admitted with EtOH intox.  Hosp course by problem:
.
# EtOH withdrawal: He has a known h/o EtOH withdrawel w
seizures.  When he first arrived on the floor, he required very
high dosages of valium (up to 140 per day).  Thus, he was
briefly transferred to the ICU for closer monitoring.  He did
well in the ICU and was transferred back to the floor.  There
his CIWA scale was initially in the 15-20 range and improved
with valium (up to 100 per day).  The patient was seen by
psychiatry and we put him on a strict valium taper.  He
tolerated this fairly well over the course of several days.  He
did have anxiety as below which likely lengthened the valium
taper.  We had the patient evaluated by case management as well
as social work and psych placement services to assess for
outpatient withdrawal/recovery services.  However, quite
abruptly, the patient decided he needed to make an appointment
on [**5-9**].  We would not prescribe a [**Month/Day (4) **] upon discharge but
instead wrote for a short course of seroquel.  He was aware of
the fact that we might have had placement for him within a few
days but refused such an investigation.
.
# Hypothyroid: patient reported good compliance with synthroid
as an outpatient (although did not take any other meds).  His
TSH was high so we increased the synthroid.  We recommend
followup TSH in [**3-7**] weeks.
.
# HTN: likely combination of withdrawal and noncompliance with
home regimen.  we restarted his home meds and he did well.
However, on [**5-5**], he had assymptomatic hypotension with systolic
in the 80s which responded to IVF.  We decreased his lisinopril
with good effect.
.
# CV:
a) Coronaries: no known CAD; ruled out for MI by enzymes;
continued ASA 81 mg daily for ppx.  While in the ICU, he did
have a brief episode of chest pain which was not accompanied by
EKG changes or any elevation in enzymes.
b) Dilated CMY (EF 25%): appears euvolemic to slightly dry.
- cont outpt lasix and spironalactone doses, watched fluid
status and followed renal function.  Did well.
- cont outpt digoxin for inotropy
.
# Transaminitis: likely from HCV plus etoh toxicity. LFT's at
baseline per report. Pt unlikely to be a candidate for treatment
with interferon given significant psychiatric and behavioral
comordities
- counselled about the importance of abstaining from any further
etoh
- hep B serologies as above
.
# Anxiety: multiple life stressors, including girlfriend out of
town and apparent movie deal involving patient and his family
- social work assisted with his care.  psychiatry also saw
patient and helped with the valium taper.  We were however
reluctant to prescribe benzos upon dispo which is why we used
many resources to search for a detox center, which he refused.
- pt had an appt with a psychiatrist as an outpatient on [**5-29**]
per his report; We contact[**Name (NI) **] the facility prior to discharge and
were unable to move the appointment to a closer date.
.
# FEN. Low Na, heart healthy diet
.
# PPX. SC heparin, PPI, bowel regimen
.

Brief Hospital Course:
86 yo female with history of afib with SSS on coumadin, HTN,
hyperlipidemia who presents from ALF with worsening dyspnea,
treated in MICU for NSTEMI, CHF and PNA.
.
# NSTEMI:  In the setting of her acute illness the patient
suffered an NSTEMI with Trop increasing from <.01 to peak of
0.77, since trending downward. Cardiology was consulted with
recommendation to treat comorbidities and maximize med regimen
without likely plan for cath. However, given NSTEMI exacerbated
by afib with RVR and history of likely tachy-brady, EP consulted
as well. Patient is currently well rate controlled with
Metoprolol with potential plan for PPM at some point in future.
.
# Dyspnea: Likely multifactorial including PNA, CHF.  In the
MICU, the patient initially required BiPap for resp distress.
She was subsequently diuresed and started on broad spectrum
coverage abx (Vanc/Zosyn/Flagyl) given fever on admission and
course pulmonary exam. With above treatment patient's fever
curve improved as did her resp status.  Antibiotics were then
narrowed to levofloxacin and she will complete a 14 day course
to finish on [**2150-2-16**].  Of note, she did have LLE swelling on
admission which has since resolved, but LENIs neg for DVT.
.
# CHF: Echo done in [**8-20**] with EF >70. Likely [**1-16**] diastolic
dysfunction.  She was initially diuresed aggressively, but her
diuretics were discontinued when she appeared clinically
euvolemic, if not mildly dry [**1-16**] to decreased PO intake.  Her
fluid status will need to be continually addressed while in
rehab with reinitiation of her diuretics as needed accordingly.
.
#. Pneumonia: was on vanc/zosyn/azithro in ICU for LLL opacity
on CXR. Changed to levaquin PO for ? CAP/asp.  She was not
covered for hospital acquired infection (gram negatives and
MRSA), but doubt that based on clinical status and CXR findings.
 She has remained afebrile without leukocytosis since initiation
of abx.  Her pulmonary exam remains rhonchorus and she has not
been able to clear her secretions well.  Chest PT was initiated
with improvement in her O2 saturation on room air.  Aggressive
pulmonary toilet should be continued in rehab as well.  If
clinical status were to deteriorate, broadening antibiotic
coverage to include hospital acquired infections is very
reasonable given her multiple hospital and rehab admissions.
Respiratory and blood cultures were negative.  She is to
complete a 14 day course of levofloxacin on [**2150-2-16**].  She was
maintaining oxygen saturations in the low to mid 90s (increasing
to high 90s with chest PT) at time of discharge.
.
#. COPD: likely experiencing exacerbation [**1-16**] pneumonia.
Although predominantly rhonchorus on exam, she did have
intermittent wheezing.  She was continued on advair,
albuterol/atrovent nebulizers, which have improved her
bronchospastic symptoms and exam findings.
.
#. CAD: Patient with troponin elevation, peak 0.77 and
subsequent downward trend. Likely a demand picture in setting of
afib with RVR, PNA, and CHF with resultant hypoxia in the unit.
She was started on plavix for anticipated cath but no plan for
that currently so it was discontinued.  She will be continued on
ASA and statin for discharge.
.
#. Atrial fibrillation: Known history of a. fib with history of
likely SSS, previously requiring temporary pacing.  Had 2
episodes of A-fib w/ RVR on [**2-5**], which were largely
unresponsive to IV lopressor, but broke with diltiazem 10-20 mg
IV.  She will be continued on PO metoprolol at 50mg QID.  Her
coumadin was originally held for the potential of PPM placement
by EP.  However, given her pulmonary status currently, there are
holding on PPM placement currently.  She does, however, have
outpatient follow up with EP on [**2150-4-15**] at which time this will
be readdressed.  Currently, she remains on heparin gtt and will
be restarted on coumadin.  Weight based heparin gtt (as included
in discharge paperwork) can be discontinued when her INR is
again therapeutic, but this will need to be followed in rehab.
.
#.  Hematuria:  While on the heparin gtt, she developed
hematuria via her foley 1 day prior to admission.  There were no
clots.  Hct and HD were entirely stable in this setting.  Her
foley catheter was discontinued and her UA did not reveal
evidence of infection.  She was able to void without difficulty
and she denied urinary symptoms.  A urine cx is currently
pending and should be followed up.  She should call [**Hospital1 18**]
urology at([**Telephone/Fax (1) 772**] for a follow up appointment to further
evaluate this if persists.
.
#. Anemia: baseline HCT 25-30.  Stable throughout hospital
course.  Should be monitored at rehab given anticoagulation and
recent hematuria.
.
#. ARF:  She had a very mild bump in her creatinine to 1.2 (BL
creatinine nml) just prior to discharge and clinically on exam
appeared to be dry with dry MM.  Creatinine normalized on day of
d/c to 1.0 after small IV fluid bolus.  Prior to her creatinine
bump, she had been kept NPO for the potential PPM placement.
Her diet has since been restarted and she was given a small
fluid bolus (given known CHF and recent aggressive diuresis).
Her kidney function and fluid status should be monitored at
rehab as well.
.
#. Depression:  She was continued on Celexa per her outpatient
regimen.
.
#. FEN:  Low sodium, heart healthy diet, ground, thick liquids.
Given concern for aspiration pneumonia, she was evaluated by
speech and swallow twice during this stay and was cleared to
take PO (ground and thin liquids) diet without evidence of
aspiration.
.
#  On [**2150-2-10**], primary team was notified that patient had a bed
at [**Hospital 100**] rehab and she was discharged there.  However, upon
arrival to [**Hospital 100**] rehab, transport team was informed that there
was no bed available.  Thus, she was transferred back to [**Hospital1 18**]
in the care of original team and nursing staff.  She was
discharged to [**Hospital 100**] Rehab on [**2150-2-11**].

   62yo M former tobacco smoker with family history of early CAD
presents with episode of chest pain.  The chest pain is
described as crushing chest pain located across the chest.  The
pain occurred while asleep at 2AM and woke him up.  There was no
radiation and was not associated with any sob, diaphoresis, n/v.
 The patient took one maalox without any improvement.  He
subsequently took one adult ASA and went to the local hospital.
There he was diagnosed with STEMI with 0.5mm elevation of ST
segment in III and aVF.  He was started on heparin gtt and
transferred directly to the catheterization lab.  In hindsight,
he reports an episode of shortness of breath while shoveling
dirt in his driveway the day prior to admission.

CARDIAC CATHETERIZATION [**2126-5-10**]:
COMMENTS:
  1. Selective coronary angiography revealed a right dominant
system.
The RCA had a long 60% mid vessel lesion and was totally
occluded in the
mid to distal vesel with left to right collaterals to the distal
vessel.
The LMCA had a 60% distal lesion. The LAD had a 70% mid vessel
lesion.
The D1 had a 70% lesion. The LCX had a 70% ostial lesion. The
first
major OM had a 80% lesion.
  2. Hemodynamics post PCI showed normal central pressure,
mildly
elevated left sided filling pressures, and a normal cardiac
index.
  3. After the export catheter was used during the procedure,
the
patient had a bradycardic episode to HR 32 with decreased blood
pressure
- which required atropine. Pacer was introduced, but patient did
not
require pacing.
  4. Successful Primary PCI of the RCA with two overlapping
Cypher DES
(3.5 x 33 mm, post-dilated with a 4.0 mm balloon, and 3.0 x 33
mm,
post-dilated with a 3.5 mm balloon).

FINAL DIAGNOSIS:
1. Three vessel coronary artery disease.
2. Mildly elevated left sided filling pressure.
3. Acute inferior myocardial infarction, managed by acute PCI of
the
RCA.
.
.

INTERPRETATION:

Findings:

LEFT ATRIUM: Mild LA enlargement.
RIGHT ATRIUM/INTERATRIAL SEPTUM: Moderately dilated RA.
LEFT VENTRICLE: Normal LV wall thickness. Normal LV cavity size.
Moderate
regional LV systolic dysfunction. No LV mass/thrombus.
RIGHT VENTRICLE: Normal RV chamber size and free wall motion.

AORTA: Normal ascending, transverse and descending thoracic
aorta with no
atherosclerotic plaque.
AORTIC VALVE: Normal aortic valve leaflets (3). No AS. No AR.
MITRAL VALVE: Normal mitral valve leaflets. Mild to moderate
([**2-10**]+) MR. LV inflow pattern c/w impaired relaxation.

TRICUSPID VALVE: Normal tricuspid valve leaflets with trivial
TR. Borderline PA systolic hypertension.

PERICARDIUM: No pericardial effusion.

Conclusions:
The left atrium is mildly dilated. The right atrium is
moderately dilated. Left ventricular wall thicknesses are
normal. The left ventricular cavity size is normal. There is
moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with
akinesis of the inferior wall and hypokinesis of the
infero-septum and infero-lateral walls. No masses or thrombi are
seen in the left ventricle. Right ventricular chamber size and
free wall motion are normal. The ascending, transverse and
descending thoracic aorta are normal in diameter and free of
atherosclerotic plaque. The aortic valve leaflets (3) appear
structurally normal with good leaflet excursion and no aortic
regurgitation. The mitral valve leaflets are structurally
normal. Mild to moderate ([**2-10**]+) mitral regurgitation is seen.
The left ventricular inflow pattern suggests impaired
relaxation. There is borderline pulmonary artery systolic
hypertension. There is no pericardial effusion.

IMPRESSION: Moderate regional LV systolic dysfunction c/w CAD.




Brief Hospital Course:
A/P: 61yo M former tob smoker with family history of early CAD
who presents with STEMI s/p cath with 3VD and PCI of RCA.
.
1.  CV:
A).  Coronaries: Pt presented to OSH with chest pain and was
found to have an STEMI.  He was transferred to [**Hospital1 18**], where he
underwent urgent cardiac catheterization.  The cath demonstrated
left main and 3v CAD and the patient underwent a PCI of RCA
which was thought to be the culprit lesion based on angiographic
findings.  After his cardiac catheterization, he was monitored
on telemetry and managed medically.  He was initially ordered
for metoprolol 12.5mg [**Hospital1 **] which was subsequently held and then
d/c'd due to bradycardia.  He was started on ACEI which he
tolerated as well as ASA and Plavix.  He was also given lipitor
80mg QHS initially, but this was also stopped due to elevated
LFT.  The patient requires a repeat LFT and Cholesterol panel as
outpatient to be re-evaluated for statin therapy.  Pt was
successfully rate and pressure controlled with goal of: HR <70
and SBP <120.  The patient received a surgical evaluation for
possible CABG on [**2126-5-23**], he was already evaluated by anesthesia
while in house as well.  Pt is to call Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] for an
outpatient appointment as he still requires a carotid US prior
to undergoing CABG.
.
B).  Pump: Pt with STEMI, and unknown pre-MI cardiac function.
TTE demonstrates a reduced EF of 35%.  Given lack of clinical
findings of CHF, he was not actively diuresed.  He was however
counseled on fluid and salt balance and given some education on
dietary control.
.
C).  Rhythm: The patient was monitored on telemtry during the
duration of his stay and he was in NSR to sinus bradycardia
during his admission.  His bradycardia limitted use of beta
blocker.  This should be re-addressed as an outpatient.
.
D).  Primary risk reduction:  The patient was initially started
on lipitor 80mg QHS given his ACS.  However due to slightly
elevated LFT, the statins were held.  We recommend outpatient
follow up of his LFT and cholesterol.  If LFTs are normal, the
patient will benefit from statins.  The patient was counsel on
lifestyle, diet, and exercise and their impact on his
cardiovascular as well as generalized health.  Even though his
FS and glucose on chemistries were wnl, his A1c was 6.4
suggesting some degree of glucose intolerance.  We recommend an
outpatient follow up of his glucose and A1c levels as
uncontrolled blood sugars have been shown to have an effect on
mortality.
.
.
2.  LBP: pt with hx of LBP.  He was given percocet PRN after
cath with good control.
.
.
3.  Elevated LFT: AST:ALT of 2.5 to 1 ratio suggestive of
possibly Alc liver disease.  Currently no sign of cirrhosis with
intact synthetic function.  Although he was initially started on
lipitor, this was stopped once his LFT were returned.  Suggest
outpatient LFT check and re-administration of lipitor if
possible.
.
.
4.  PPx: Pt was initially on integrillin after cath and then
subsequently on Heparin subQ TID for DVT prophylaxis.  Colace,
senna for bowel regimen, and PPI for ICU stress were also given
during his stay.
.

Medications on Admission:
Aspirin

readjusted as needed.

acute flare.  Otherwise you should continue with allopurinol at

text:
Admission Date:  [**2113-10-26**]       Discharge Date:  [**2113-11-28**]


Service:  CARDIOTHORACIC SURGERY

HISTORY OF THE PRESENT ILLNESS:  This 85-year-old female
presented to an outside hospital with substernal chest pain
radiating to her neck and back with shortness of breath and
nausea.  The episode lasted about an hour and resolved
spontaneously.  It recurred later that evening but did not
resolve.  She was brought to the Emergency Room and was
hemodynamically stable.  EKG changes were noted at that time.
Cardiology was called.  The patient still had significant
chest pain and had received sublingual nitroglycerin and was
on a nitroglycerin drip, beta blocker, aspirin, and heparin
drip and was transferred into [**Hospital1 **].

ALLERGIES:  The patient is allergic to sulfa.

MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION:
1.  Bumex 0.5 once a day.
2.  K-Dur 20 once a day.
3.  Avapro 300 once a day.
4.  Atenolol 50 once a day.
5.  Calcium.
6.  Multivitamin.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  The patient lives alone.  The patient has no
alcohol history.  The patient has no smoking history.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1.  Hypertension.
2.  Hypercholesterolemia.
3.  History of right total knee replacement.
4.  History of polypectomy in [**2113-8-20**] without GI
bleed.

When she was brought into [**Hospital3 **], she was taken to the
cardiac catheterization laboratory which showed the
following:  Cardiac output 2.1, left main 30%, LAD 100%
occlusion, circumflex 90% occlusion, and RCA 90% occlusion
with a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 25.
Intra-aortic balloon pump was placed in the Cardiac
Catheterization Laboratory and the patient remained on IV
heparin, IV Integrelin, IV nitroglycerin, and was receiving
aspirin and Plavix.  The diagnosis was a posterolateral
myocardial infarction based on EKG changes and laboratory
work.

She was referred to Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] and was seen first by
Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 21815**], Cardiac Surgery, Chief Resident, who
noted her index at 1.5.  She was alert and oriented, a rather
small petite woman.  Her chest was clear.  Her heart sounds
were distant.  In addition, she had no carotid bruits.  She
had no murmur.  Her abdominal examination was benign.  Her
leg showed no varicosities with good distal pulses.

Her preoperative laboratory work showed a sodium of 130, K
8.6, chloride 98, C02 21, BUN 38, creatinine 1.6.  Her CK was
199.  Her white count was 11.2, platelet count 285,000, and
hematocrit of 41 with an INR of 1.1.  He noted her diagnosis
of acute myocardial infarction and recommended an
echocardiogram to evaluate her ventricular function.

The patient initially refused surgery on the night of the 7th
but agreed that it was her best option the following morning.
She was taken to the Operating Room after the echocardiogram
was performed at night which was a limited examination,
according to the cardiology note, but the LV ejection
fraction appeared well preserved without any focal wall
motion abnormalities.  There was also no significant MR, TR
and 1+ AI.  There was a small pericardial effusion versus a
fat pad.  Please refer to the cardiology note by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 976**].

The patient was seen again on the morning of [**2113-11-26**]
by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **] and on [**2113-11-26**] went to the Operating
Room.  She had a coronary artery bypass grafting times four
with a LIMA to the diagonal, vein graft to the LAD, vein
graft to the PDA, and a vein graft to the OM by Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) **].
The intra-aortic balloon pump was still in place in the right
femoral artery.

The patient was transferred to the ICU in stable condition on
a dobutamine drip at 5 micrograms per kilogram per minute,
Neo-Synephrine drip at 0.3 micrograms per kilogram per
minute, and a propofol drip at 10 micrograms per kilogram per
minute.

The patient also got a transfusion for some blood loss
postoperatively.  On postoperative day number one, the
patient had been extubated the night prior, was
hemodynamically stable with a blood pressure of 100/40, CVP
14, and output of 3.3, index 2.1.  The balloon was on 1:2
weaning mode.  The white count was 14.2, hematocrit 26.5,
platelet count 93,000.  The first postoperative laboratories
also included a sodium of 132, K 5.1, chloride 108, C02 18,
BUN 23, creatinine 1.3, blood sugar 84.

The lungs had decreased breath sounds at the bases. The heart
revealed a regular rate and rhythm.  The chest tubes had no
leak.  The abdomen was soft. The chest incision was clean,
dry, and intact.  The extremities were warm.  She was alert
without any neurological deficits.  She was receiving

text:
Admission Date:  [**2171-7-29**]       Discharge Date:  [**2171-9-13**]

Date of Birth:   [**2121-1-27**]       Sex:  F

Service:  TRANSPLANT SURGERY

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a 50 year-old
female with a history of positive kidney disease and
polycystic liver disease who presented on [**7-28**] preoperative
for a combined orthotopic liver and cadaveric renal
transplant.  The patient had a recent cardiac workup, which
was negative and endoscopy for gastrojejunal polyps, which
was also negative for malignancy.  The patient denied fevers
or chills, coughs, nausea, vomiting, chest pain or shortness
of breath, bowel and bladder dysfunction.  The patient had a
history of multiple abdominal surgeries and massive ventral
hernias with very little abdominal wall left.  The patient
was last seen in the [**Hospital 1326**] Clinic in [**2171-4-6**].  The
patient also had family members that suffered from polycystic
kidney disease with family members with cadaveric kidney
transplants.  She also had family members that suffered from
polycystic liver disease as well consistent with abdominal
dominant inheritance.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Polycystic liver and kidney disease.
Multiple ventral hernia repairs in [**2161**].  Anemia.
Hypertension.  Total abdominal hysterectomy.  Bilateral
salpingo-oophorectomy.  Status post cholecystectomy in [**2153**].
Status post appendectomy in [**2155**].  Status post exploratory
laparotomy LOA in [**2163**].

MEDICATIONS:
1.  Aldactone.
2.  Lasix.
3.  Norvasc.
4.  Mycelex.

ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  The patient does not drink or smoke.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION ON ADMISSION:  Afebrile, blood pressure
114/62, 81, 20, 98% on room air.  The patient weighed 105
kilograms.  The patient was awake and alert on physical
examination and abdominal examination showed obese massive
ventral hernias with an ulcer on the left side, surgical
scars well healed, soft and nontender.  The rest of the
patient's physical examination on admission was unremarkable.

LABORATORY:  The patient has a TSH on admission of 3.5,
hepatitis B and A negative.  HIV negative.  Echocardiogram
showed normal left ventricular ejection fraction, normal PAP.
Stress test was normal.  Gastrojejunal biopsy was negative
for malignancy.  Chest x-ray was clear.  White blood cell
count 7.8, hematocrit 33, platelets 233, fibrinogen of 438,
urinalysis negative.  Chemistry showed a sodium of 137,
potassium 4.5, chloride 103, bicarb 20, BUN 74, creatinine
2.4, glucose 120.  Serologies included EBV, IGG positive by
EIA.  RPR was nonreactive.  CMV positive, VZV positive,
rubella IGG positive [**2171-6-19**], toxo IGG negative.

PROCEDURES DURING HOSPITAL COURSE:
1.  Orthotopic liver transplantation and cadaveric renal
transplantation combined procedure [**7-29**].
2.  Perforated small bowel oversewn [**8-4**].
3.  Hemoperitoneum with exploratory laparotomy [**8-15**].
4.  Perforated colonic anastomosis status post transverse
colectomy, [**Doctor Last Name 3379**] pouch and end colostomy on [**8-24**].

HOSPITAL COURSE:  Cadaveric kidney transplantation,
orthotopic liver transplantation combined procedure was
performed on [**2171-7-29**].  The patient had a kidney transplant
that was intraperitoneal with ureterurostomy with stent and a
right native nephrectomy.  The patient had an orthotopic
liver transplantation at the same time with prolonged
hospital course as well as Intensive Care Unit stay.  Initial
operations complicated by dense adhesions for multiple
previous operations, which took approximately three hours to
enter the abdomen.  During the course of the adhesiolysis a
colotomy was made in the transverse colon requiring sleeve
resection.  The patient also had serosal tear of small bowel,
which was repaired.  The patient was transferred to the
Intensive Care Unit for postoperative care.  On [**8-4**] the
patient developed pneumoperitoneum and was taken back to the
Operating Room where a small bowel perforation was found and
repaired.  Even preoperatively the patient had large amount
of ascitic fluid requiring 8 liters of paracentesis
preoperatively.  Postoperatively, the patient had very large
acidic output over 3 liters a day.  Postoperatively, the
patient care was complicated by bouts of atrial fibrillation
and echocardiogram by cardiology by cardiology revealed
pericardial effusion and tamponade physiology without
systemic hemodynamic systems.  Repeat echocardiogram revealed
increased tamponade with worsening tamponade physiology.  For
this, on the evening the [**7-15**] pericardiocentesis was
performed.  The patient was returned to the Intensive Care
Unit when hematocrit began to fall and rapid atrial
fibrillation ensued.  The patient was taken emergently to the
Operating Room where she was found to have a pericardial
drain in the pericardium and a large hemoperitoneum.  The
patient's abdomen was washed out for hemoperitoneum and the
pericardial window was performed with follow up
echocardiogram that showed complete resolution of the
pericardial effusion.

On the 19th the patient again developed worsening
pneumoperitoneum and was taken back to the Operating Room for
exploratory laparotomy.  The patient was found to have
completely walled off abscess at the site of the previous
colonic resection.  The patient had a transverse colectomy,
Hartmann's pouch and ascending colostomy.  The patient was
washed out and drains were placed.  The remainder of the
[**Hospital 228**] hospital course was noted as being normal with
normal hepatic function, creatinine that remained at 2.5 and
3 liters of acidic output a day.  Acidic creatinine was 2.7.
Because of high index suspicion nuclear renal scan was
obtained and demonstrated urinary leak.  Cystoscopy was
performed demonstrating migration of the stent into the
ureter and two areas of leak.  A bridging stent was placed
across.  The remainder of the hospital course showed noted
improvement.  The patient was advanced to and tolerated a
regular diet with normal colostomy function.  Creatinine
decreased to 1.0 and JP output decreased to 30 cc and was
removed.  The patient is currently working with physical
therapy and is out of bed to chair.

The patient is to be discharged to rehabilitation on [**2171-9-13**] to have immunosuppressive medications adjusted
according to blood levels by transplant team only and blood
work every Monday and Thursday in the a.m. prior to Neoral
and Prograf ingestion.  CBC with differential, chem 7,
calcium, magnesium, phosphate, albumin, AST, ALT, alkaline
phosphatase, T bili, direct bili and either Prograf or
Cyclosporin level depending upon which drug the patient is
taking at the time.  Laboratory results need to be faxed to
[**Telephone/Fax (1) 697**] on the same day they are drawn.  The patient is
to have clinic visit every Wednesday at [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 439**]
[**Location (un) **] for the first three months.  Follow up is scheduled
and dates and times will be provided to the patient.  Contact
person for patient is [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1022**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], R.N. liver transplant
coordinator at [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10575**], direct line or main number is
[**Telephone/Fax (1) 673**].  Please notify transplant coordinator at least
two days prior to discharge from rehabilitation to order a
shipment of transplant medications.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
1.  Bactrim 400-80 mg tablets one po q.d.
2.  Valcyte 450 mg tablet one po q.o.d.
3.  MMF 500 mg tablet two tablets po b.i.d.
4.  Lasix 40 mg tablet one tablet po q.d.
5.  Prednisone 5 mg tablet 2.5 tablets po q.d.
6.  Fluconazole 200 mg tablet one po q.d.
7.  Protonix 40 mg tablet one po q.d.
8.  Amiodarone 300 mg tablet one po q.d.
9.  Nystatin suspension.
10.  Cyclosporin 125 mg b.i.d. po.

DISCHARGE STATUS:  To rehabilitation.

DISCHARGE CONDITION:  Good.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1.  Status post orthotopic liver transplantation, cadaveric
kidney transplantation combined procedure.
2.  Small bowel perforation oversewn.
3.  Exploratory laparotomy.
4.  Colonic anastomosis status post transverse colectomy,
Hartmann's and end colostomy.







                            [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 707**], M.D.,Ph.D.

text:
Admission Date:  [**2163-6-25**]       Discharge Date:

Date of Birth:   [**2090-11-8**]       Sex:  F

Service:  Psychiatry

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  This is a 72 year old woman with
a history of depression and anxiety who was discharged from
the medical service three weeks ago after an admission for
shortness of breath culminating in her being sent home with
home oxygen (a new requirement).  Subsequently she had had a
nodule found on
pulmonary computerized tomography scan which was believed to
be benign, and she has been increasingly ruminative regarding
perceived financial difficulties as well as increased medical
problems.  The patient reports that her sleep has become
erratic with middle insomnia, decreased appetite, poor
concentration and depressed mood.  She has felt increasingly
withdrawn, not answering the telephone, and not checking for
e-mails.  She has imagined death as "relief," and has had
egodystonic fantasies without intent of attempting suicide
with a knife.  She feels that her difficulties have developed
in concert with worsening medical health.  In addition she
has been taking very poor care of herself, struggling even to
get dressed in the morning.  On the day of admission the
patient had been stating to her daughter, "everything is
wrong."  She has been perseverative regarding
unwarranted (according to multiple collaterals) financial
concerns (similar to the way she was
after her husband's death and after this event she had
attempted suicide).  The patient had repeated to her daughter
"I'm going to die, my head is going to make me die."  The
patient would not hang up the phone with her daughter out of
fear that she would die.

PAST PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY:  Two prior psychiatric admissions,
one at the age of 18 at the Institute of Living for
Depression and Anxiety, the second one 11 years ago at [**Hospital6 1760**] after a suicide attempt via
overdose after the death of her husband.  The patient has
been seeing Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] the past 11 years and sees him now
about once a year.  She has never been tried on an SSRI.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  1.  Congestive heart failure,
secondary to viral cardiomyopathy; 2.  Hypertension; 3.  3+
Mitral regurgitation and pulmonary hypertension; 4.  Asthma;
5.  Kyphoscoliosis and severe restrictive lung disease; 6.
Unilateral vocal cord paralysis; 7.  Right middle lobe lung
nodule noted on computerized tomography scan of the chest in
[**2161-12-1**].

MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION:
1.  Digoxin .25 mg p.o. t.i.d.
2.  Metoprolol 50 mg p.o. b.i.d.
3.  Lasix 40 mg p.o. q.d.
4.  Thiamine 100 mg p.o. q.d.
5.  Folate 1 mg p.o. q.d.
6.  Zestril 20 mg p.o. b.i.d.
7.  Albuterol 1 to 2 puffs q. 12 hours
8.  Fluticasone 2 puffs b.i.d.
9.  Multivitamin p.o. q.d.
10. Lipitor 10 mg p.o. q.d.
11. Desipramine 50 mg p.o. q.d.
12. Aspirin 81 mg p.o. q.d.
13. Fosamax 70 mg p.o. q. week
14. Home oxygen at 2 liters per minute

In addition the patient takes antibiotics prior to any dental
work.

ALLERGIES:  No known drug allergies.

SUBSTANCE ABUSE HISTORY:  The patient denies any history of
alcohol or drug abuse.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  The patient has been widowed for 11 years.
She is a mother of two with a daughter and a son and has
three grandchildren.  She worked at [**Location 24537**] a
womens program for 29 years up until about ten years ago.
She currently lives in [**Location 745**] with her boyfriend of 7 1/2
years.  She reports that her husband who died 11 years ago
was an alcoholic.  She denies any current or past history of
domestic violence.

FAMILY PSYCHIATRIC HISTORY:  Depression and suicide attempt
in a brother.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  Physical examination on admission
revealed her to be afebrile with vital signs stable.
Physical examination was notable for marked kyphoscoliosis,
III/VI systolic murmur on cardiac examination and extremities
were notable for 1+ edema bilaterally to mid calf.

LABORATORY DATA:  On admission complete blood count was
notable for white count of 13.8 which decreased to 10 on
repeat.  Chem-10 was notable for an elevated bicarbonate at
40, liver function tests were normal, RPR nonreactive, TSH
was 2.0.  Serum and urine toxicology screens were negative
including serum tricyclic level was negative and arterial
blood gases performed on [**6-26**] was 7.43/56/107/45.  An
electrocardiogram was performed which showed sinus rhythm,
premature atrial contractions, interventricular conduction
delays, possible left ventricular hypertrophy, anterolateral
ST abnormality with no change from the previous
electrocardiogram of [**5-30**].  Chest x-ray showed severe
scoliosis with clear lungs and no effusions.  Chest
computerized tomography scan performed just prior to
admission showed a stable right middle lobe nodule sized at 3
mm and a new left upper lobe nodule sized at 5 mm.

MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION:  The patient was neatly dressed
wearing oxygen via nasal cannula and pushing an oxygen tank.
She appeared slightly older than her stated age.  She made
good eye contact.  [**Name (NI) **] speech was hoarse, slightly slowed
with increased latent periods.  Her mood was "overwhelmed."
Her affect was dysphoric.  Her thought process was slow but
linear.  Her thought content was focused on financial
worries.  She admitted to thoughts of death as "relief" and
occasional egodystonic fantasies of suicide via knife but
when she reached the inpatient unit she adamantly denied
suicidal intent.  She had no psychotic symptoms but severe
rumination regarding medical condition and preoccupations of
guilt, stating her belief that she had become a burden for
her family.  Her cognitive examination was grossly intact.
Her insight and judgment were good.  She had great difficulty
maintaining hope.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  Medical course - The patient's primary care
physician, [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **]. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1007**], followed her closely
(with daily visits) throughout her
hospital stay.  She was
continued on her pre-admission outpatient medications.  The blood
gases noted above showed a mildly increased carbon dioxide
compared to her baseline of 66 up from 60.  The patient,
however, was continued on oxygen at 2 liters/minute as this
was considered to be an insignificant change.  Given the
history of lung nodules, a head computerized tomography scan
was obtained to rule out brain metastases from a possible
cancer and the head computerized tomography scan was negative
for metastases.  The patient had recently had a sleep study
as an outpatient that indicated that CPAP could be helpful.
A pulmonary consultation was obtained and BiPAP was
recommended.  She was started on BiPAP and tolerated a
setting of [**9-4**] (she will follow up in the sleep clinic with
Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] for this).  A second arterial blood gases on room
air showed significant hypoxia with a pO2 of 45 and a pCO2 of
60, so continue with oxygen, not just on exertion was
recommended.  The patient also complained of sporadic
monocular diplopia with [**Location (un) 1131**] which she thought had started
prior to admission.  An ophthalmology consultation was
obtained and they report that the symptoms can be consistent
with dry eyes caused by the increased flow of air from the
oxygen.  Preservative free eye drops were started with good
effect.  The patient was also seen by her cardiologist for
increased pedal edema.  He recommended adding an additional
40 mg of Furosemide in the afternoon every other day with
supplemental potassium every other day.  He said her goal
weight should be roughly 137 lb.  He recommended daily
weights and monitoring of the BUN and creatinine every week.
Her weight fell to 136 after starting the additional
Furosemide and BUN and creatinine remained within normal
limits.  Elastic stockings were also begun per the patient's
primary care physician, [**Name10 (NameIs) **], the patient's edema
continued up to the point of this dictation.

[**Hospital 7637**] hospital course - The patient was admitted
voluntarily to the Inpatient Psychiatric Service.  The
Desipramine was tapered off given that it was ineffective at
the current dose and the cardiotoxic interactions are more
likely at higher doses.  Citalopram was started at 10 mg p.o.
q.d. and slowly increased up to 40 mg p.o. q.d.  (Citalopram
was found to have no significant interactions with the
patient's current medications on a Micromedex search.)  She
was continued on her longterm medication of Clonazepam at a
low dose of 0.5 mg t.i.d.  Neuropsychiatric testing was
performed.  The patient was noted to have reduced verbal
learning and reduced rapid retrieval of information.  She was
also noted to have decreased visual scanning.  These problems
were thought to be consistent with vascular changes from
chronic obstructive pulmonary disease though an ongoing
dementing process could not be ruled out.  An occupational
therapy safety assessment was performed and found that the
patient had the safety skills to return to her own home.  An
occupational therapy home assessment was recommended along
with [**Hospital6 407**] services when she does return
home.  Occupational therapy worked extensively with the
patient regarding how to deal with her oxygen tank.  In
general, the patient was very focused on her oxygen tank and
her perceived inability to learn how to handle it (and
particularly that the tank would run out of oxygen). Her
ruminations also included worries about running out of money,
running out of insurance and concerns that her daughter would
have to give up graduate school because of her illness.  She
was frustrated by the resistance of her illness to treatment
and as her depression proved difficult to treat
electroconvulsive therapy was considered, however, the
[**Hospital 228**] medical problems (d/w'ed PCP and patient's
cardiologist) would put her at much higher risk
than the average patient so it was decided to continue with
medication treatment.  Given the ruminative parapsychotic
nature of the depression, antipsychotic therapy with
quetiapine was started on [**7-8**].  She noted severe
morning sedation on the quetiapine at a dose of 50 mg
q.h.s., so she was switched to Risperidone which was much
less sedating.  As the patient continued to express inability
to concentrate and very low energy, it was decided to start a
trial of Ritalin after telephone consultation with the
covering cardiologist.  The patient has not yet received her
first dose of Ritalin at the time of this dictation.
Multiple family meetings were held with the patient's son and
daughter.  The patient's long time boyfriend did not
participate in formal family meetings, though he was
encouraged to do and did communicate with team members
individually.

The rest of the hospital course, discharge diagnosis,
discharge medications and follow up plans will be dictated in
an addendum to this discharge summary when the patient is
discharged from the hospital.



                            [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 23995**], M.D.  [**MD Number(1) 23996**]

Downsloping ST depressions of 1 mm to 2 mm in size in leads
I, II, aVF, and V3 through V6.

A chest x-ray revealed severe kyphoscoliosis.  No acute
infiltrate.  No evidence of congestive heart failure.

CONCISE SUMMARY OF HOSPITAL COURSE BY ISSUE/SYSTEM:

1.  RESPIRATORY ISSUES:  The patient presented to the Medical
Intensive Care Unit after an episode of hypercarbic
respiratory failure.

A chest x-ray showed minimal evidence of congestive heart
failure.  Therefore, a pulmonary embolism was suspected.
However, a chest computerized axial tomography with
angiography ruled out this diagnosis.

The patient's presentation was also suspicious a myocardial
infarction.  Cardiac enzymes were checked every eight hours
times three following the respiratory decompensation.
Creatine phosphokinase levels were found not to be elevated.
At troponin level did reach 0.1 on the second set.

A Cardiology consultation was obtained, and an echocardiogram
was done.  The patient was found to have no focal wall motion
abnormalities, left ventricular ejection fraction was 55%,
and severe 4+ mitral regurgitation.  Per the Cardiology
consultation, there was no evidence to support a myocardial
infarction and that the majority of the electrocardiogram
changes were felt to be consistent with prior examinations.

The patient's blood pressure was controlled initially with a
nitroglycerin drip during extubation on [**7-20**].
Overnight, the patient was weaned off the nitroglycerin drip
and started on a course of isosorbide dinitrate and
hydralazine as needed for blood pressure control.  Cardiology
advised bringing her systolic blood pressures close to 100.
As the patient is a chronic CO2 retainer, her oxygen
saturations were kept in the low 90s for the remainder of her
hospital stay.

Of note, on her computerized axial tomography two stable
pulmonary nodules with some surrounding lymphadenopathy were
noted.

2.  INTRAVENOUS ACCESS ISSUES:  An arterial line and left
subclavian central line were placed on [**7-18**] and were
discontinued on [**7-21**] in preparation for the patient's
discharge back to [**Hospital1 **] Four.  These lines were placed
without complications.

3.  DEPRESSION ISSUES:  The patient was very anxious
throughout her hospital stay.  All psychiatric medications;
including citalopram, Ativan, and Risperdal were continued as
previously prescribed to control her anxiety and fluctuating
mood.

4.  CARDIOVASCULAR ISSUES:  To address the patient's history
of congestive heart failure, she was continued on Lipitor, a
beta blocker, aspirin, Lasix, and digoxin as previously
prescribed.  It was thought that her respiratory failure may
have been caused by a flash pulmonary edema related to her
congestive heart failure and mitral regurgitation.

CONDITION AT DISCHARGE:  Condition on discharge was stable.
The patient had no oxygen requirement at the time of
discharge.

MEDICATIONS ON DISCHARGE:
 1.  Ativan 0.25 mg by mouth three times per day.
 2.  Risperidone 1 mg by mouth q.h.s. and 0.25 mg by mouth
twice per day as needed.
 3.  Celexa 40 mg by mouth once per day.
 4.  Aspirin 325 mg by mouth once per day.
 5.  Lipitor 10 mg by mouth once per day.
 6.  Multivitamin one tablet by mouth once per day.
 7.  Digoxin 0.25 mg by mouth once per day.
 8.  Metoprolol 50 mg by mouth twice per day.
 9.  Lasix 40 mg by mouth once per day.
10.  Thiamine 100 mg by mouth once per day.
11.  Folate 1 mg by mouth once per day.
12.  Zestril 20 mg by mouth once per day.
13.  Albuterol inhaler 1 to 2 puffs inhaled q.12h.
14.  Flovent 2 puffs inhaled q.12h.
15.  Fosamax 70 mg by mouth every week.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1.  Hypercarbic respiratory failure.
2.  Congestive heart failure.
3.  Hypertension.
4.  Restrictive lung disease.
5.  Kyphoscoliosis.
6.  Major depression.

DISCHARGE DISPOSITION:  The patient was to be transferred to
[**Hospital1 **] Four, the Inpatient Psychiatry Unit, for ongoing
management of her depression and anxiety.

DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS/FOLLOWUP:  The patient was instructed
to follow up with Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 1007**] (her primary care
physician) while on [**Hospital1 **] Four.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1007**] has been
informed of the [**Hospital 228**] hospital stay.

text:
Admission Date:  [**2108-3-23**]       Discharge Date:  [**2108-4-7**]


Service:  Cardiothoracic

CHIEF COMPLAINT:  Transfer from an outside hospital for
workup and treatment of endocarditis.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  An 87 year old man with a
history of cardiomyopathy and hypertension along with sick
sinus syndrome status post pacemaker placement who was
transferred from [**Hospital6 38016**] for management
of questionable endocarditis.  The patient presented to the
[**Hospital 28159**] Hospital on [**3-21**] with complaints of 1?????? weeks
of persistent intermittent fevers, arthralgias, chills,
anorexia, nausea, vomiting and diarrhea.  The patient was
admitted to the hospital where blood culture two out of two
came back with Methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus
as did a urine culture.  The patient subsequently had a
culture on [**3-22**] which at the time of admission was growing
gram positive cocci in clusters consistent with
Staphylococcus.  The patient was initially treated with
Vancomycin but was switched to Oxacillin once the
sensitivities were returned.  He had a transesophageal
echocardiogram which revealed tricuspid vegetation and was
diagnosed with endocarditis and transferred for further
management.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  1. Cardiomyopathy; 2.  Sick sinus
syndrome, status post permanent pacer; 3.  Hypertension; 4.
Diverticulosis; 5.  Benign prostatic hypertrophy status post
transurethral resection of prostate; 6. Mild peripheral
neuropathy; 7.  Status post appendectomy; 8.  Small abdominal
aortic aneurysm; 9.  Anxiety disorder.

ALLERGIES:  The patient has no known drug allergies.

MEDICATIONS:  On transfer from [**Hospital 28159**] Hospital
1.  Amiodarone 200 mg q.d.
2.  Flonase
3.  Prevacid 30 mg q.d.
4.  Multivitamin
5.  Oxacillin 2 gm intravenously q. 6 hours
6.  Tylenol 650 q. 4 hours prn
7.  Phenergan
8.  Ativan
9.  Proscar 5 mg q.d.
10. Prozac 20 mg q.d.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  He lives with his wife in [**Name (NI) 38017**]
[**State 350**].  Son is an Infectious Disease specialist.
remote tobacco use and rare alcohol use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  Physical examination at the time of
admission revealed vital signs with heartrate of 76, blood
pressure 110/60, respiratory rate 24, and oxygen saturations
95% on 2 liters.  Temperature was 101.3.  General, alert, ill
appearing gentleman.  Head, eyes, ears, nose and throat,
pupils were equally round and reactive to light.  Extraocular
motions intact.  Mucous membranes were dry.  Oropharynx
benign.  Neck is supple with no lymphadenopathy.
Jugulovenous pressure is at 7 cm.  Cardiovascular:  Regular
rate and rhythm, II/VI systolic ejection murmur at the right
sternal border with radiation to the neck.  Respiratory is
clear to auscultation bilaterally.  Abdomen is soft,
nontender, nondistended with positive bowel sounds.
Extremities warm, no cyanosis, clubbing or edema.  Small
petechiae, left third digit and left great toe.
Neurological, alert and oriented times three.  Cranial nerves
2 through 12 grossly intact, nonfocal examination.

LABORATORY DATA:  Laboratory data at the time of admission
revealed white count 15.8, hematocrit 36.8, platelets 31,000.
INR 1.2, PTT 36.7.  Sodium 140, potassium 4.1, chloride 108,
carbon dioxide 22, BUN 43, creatinine 1.0, glucose 81.  Blood
from outside hospital on [**3-21**], 2 of 2 bottles of
Methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus, on [**3-22**], 2
of 2 bottles with gram positive cocci in clusters resembling
Staphylococcus as a preliminary report, [**3-23**], 4 of 4
bottles pending, urine from [**3-21**], Methicillin-susceptible
Staphylococcus aureus.

HOSPITAL COURSE:  Following admission the patient was seen by
Infectious Disease as well as Electrophysiology.  Repeat
transesophageal echocardiogram was done which showed a 5.5 cm
mass on the pacer wire, likely not suitable for a
transcutaneous extraction following identification of this
mass Cardiothoracic Surgery was consulted and the patient was
evaluated for open removal of his permanent pacing wires.  He
was accepted by Cardiothoracic Surgery and on [**3-28**], he
was brought to the Operating Room at which time he underwent
pacer wire extraction via sternotomy.  Please see the
operation report for full details.  The patient tolerated the
surgery well and was transferred from the Operating Room to
the Cardiothoracic Intensive Care Unit.  He did well in the
immediate postoperative period.  His anesthesia was reversed.
He was weaned from the ventilator and successfully extubated.
He remained in the Cardiothoracic Intensive Care Unit
throughout postoperative day #1 as he required Neosynephrine
infusion to maintain an adequate blood pressure.  Throughout
postoperative day #1 and in the morning of postoperative day
#2 the patient was weaned from his Neosynephrine infusion and
on the morning of postoperative day #2 he was transferred
from the Cardiothoracic Intensive Care Unit to Far 6 for
continuing postoperative care and cardiac rehabilitation. On
postoperative day #3 the patient was noted to have a period
of confusion and incoherent speech, however, his neurological
examination was nonfocal in nature.  Given the nature of the
patient's recently cardiac surgery as well as his vegetation
that was on his pacing wires the patient was brought for a
head computerized axial tomography scan to rule out an
embolic event.  The computerized axial tomography scan was
negative and the confusion was felt to be related to hospital
psychosis versus infection.  On chest x-ray the patient had a
right upper lobe infiltrate and therefore his intravenous
antibiotic coverage was expanded to include not only
Oxacillin but also Ceftazidime and Flagyl.  On postoperative
day #4 the patient's neurological status was noted to be
improved, however, at that time a new truncal rash was noted.
The rash was felt to be a result of his intravenous
antibiotic.  Because the patient had Oxacillin sensitive
Staphylococcus infection his Oxacillin was continued and his
Ceftazidime and Flagyl were discontinued.  The patient's rash
continued to be a problem extending not only to his trunk but
also to his upper extremities.  Dermatology was consulted and
they agreed that it was most likely a drug rash due to the
Oxacillin and therefore his Oxacillin was changed to
Vancomycin.  For the next several days the patient continued
to show slow progress and he remained afebrile and
hemodynamically stable and remained on his intravenous
Vancomycin and on postoperative day #8 a PICC line was placed
for longterm intravenous antibiotic use.  On postoperative
day #9 it was felt that the patient was stable and ready for
transfer to rehabilitation for continuing postoperative care
and rehabilitation.  At that time he was screened by several
rehabilitation centers.  It was expected that he will be
ready and accepted for discharge within the next several
days.  At this time the patient's condition is stable.  His
physical examination as of this time is vital signs with
temperature 98, heartrate 74 sinus rhythm, blood pressure
107/60, respiratory rate 18, and oxygen saturations 90%, on
40% shuttle.  Weight preoperatively is 82.3 kg.  At discharge
is 79.9 kg.

Laboratory data revealed white count 14.7, hematocrit 25.8,
platelets 222, PT 13.3, PTT 34.1, INR 1.2.  Sodium 135,
potassium 4.6, chloride 104, carbon dioxide 24, BUN 24,
creatinine 1.5, glucose 136.

Physical examination is alert and oriented times three.
Moves all extremities, follows all commands.  He can be
confused at times but easily reoriented. Respiratory, coarse
rhonchi throughout.  Breathsounds diminished bilaterally at
the bases, left greater than right. Strong productive cough.
Cardiovascular, regular rate and rhythm, S1 and S2.  Sternum
is stable.  Incision with steri-strips, open to air, clean
and dry.  Abdomen is soft, nontender, nondistended with
normoactive bowel sounds.  Extremities are warm and well
perfused with 1 to 2+ pedal edema.  He has a generalized rash
to the trunk, arms and legs that is resolving.

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS:
1.  Status post pacemaker lead extraction
2.  Cardiomyopathy
3.  Sick sinus syndrome
4.  Hypertension
5.  Diverticulosis
6.  Benign prostatic hypertrophy status post transurethral
resection of prostate
7.  Abdominal aortic aneurysm
8.  Status post appendectomy
9.  Mild peripheral neuropathy
10. The patient has an allergy to Oxacillin.

DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS:
1.  Colace 100 mg b.i.d.
2.  Amiodarone 200 mg q.d.
3.  Heparin 5000 units subcutaneously b.i.d.
4.  Protonix 40 mg q.d.
5.  Enteric coated Aspirin 325 q.d.
6.  Proscar 5 mg q.d.
7.  Lasix 20 mg q.d.
8.  Potassium chloride 20 mEq q.d.
9.  Vancomycin 1 gm q. 24 hours to be continued through [**4-25**]. Vancomycin levels need to be checked on [**4-8**],
following pre and post levels on [**2117-4-8**]. Motrin 600 mg q. 6 hours prn
12. Tylenol 650 mg q. 4 hours prn
13. Percocet 5/325 one to two tablets q. 4 hours prn

FOLLOW UP:  The patient is to return to [**Hospital6 649**] for a chest computerized axial tomography scan
in two weeks.  He is to have follow up with the Infectious
Disease Clinic to be arranged following his chest
computerized axial tomography scan.  He is to have follow up
with electrophysiology, Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] in six weeks and
follow up with Cardiothoracic Surgery, Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 70**]
also in six weeks, the patient's expected date of transfer to
rehabilitation is [**2108-4-8**].


                            [**First Name11 (Name Pattern1) **] [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **], M.D.  [**MD Number(1) 75**]

Dictated By:[**Name8 (MD) 415**]

text:
Admission Date:  [**2139-8-28**]       Discharge Date:  [**2139-9-21**]

Date of Birth:   [**2093-5-6**]       Sex:  M

Service:

CHIEF COMPLAINT:  Bilateral leg pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  The patient is a 46 -year-old
African American male with a history of chronic obstructive
pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, cor pulmonale,
hypertension, chronic renal insufficiency, and chronic venous
ulcers.  The patient has a complaint of three days of
worsening bilateral lower extremity pain, left greater than
right.  The patient has noticed increased pain and increased
swelling, as well as increased erythema, especially when
weight bearing.

The patient has a left lower extremity ulceration that gets
dressing changes every other day by [**Hospital6 1587**].  The patient has stopped taking Lasix because he
has an increased bicarbonate level and it was restarted a few
days ago.  The patient denies any fever or chills, rigors,
and upper extremity swelling.  The patient also has a
complaint of a cough for approximately one month that is
productive of white clear sputum.  The patient states this is
unchanged.  The patient is oxygen dependent, three liters at
home, has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and CPAP at
night for his obstructive sleep apnea.

The patient denies any shortness of breath or green sputum
production.  The patient uses metered dose inhalers at home.
The patient also complained of substernal chest pain on the
left which was non-radiating, which lasted minutes, and had
no associated symptoms.  The patient denies shortness of
breath, abdominal pain, diarrhea, melena, hematochezia,
hematemesis, upper respiratory infection symptoms, or
palpitations.  The patient has noticed a decrease in urine
output without any associated dysuria.  The patient is
unclear when Lasix was held and restarted.  The patient has
chronic renal insufficiency with a creatinine baseline at
2.5.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1.  Obesity.
2.  Obstructive sleep apnea, requiring CPAP.
3.  Hypertension.
4.  Pulmonary hypertension.
5.  Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, requiring O2 of
three liters at home.
6.  Cor pulmonale.
7.  Chronic renal insufficiency.
8.  Venous ulcers.
9.  The patient had an echocardiogram on [**2139-6-16**] which
showed an ejection fraction of over 55% with a dilated right
ventricle and hypokinesis and 3+ tricuspid regurgitation.

ADMITTING MEDICATIONS:  Include hydralazine 100 mg qid,
Lasix, Diltiazem 180 mg each day, clonidine 3.0 mg q day,
KCL, Atrovent nebulizers, Isordil 40 mg three times a day,
miconazole, Maalox, Tylenol, Nystatin powder, Usaryl.

ALLERGIES:  Keflex and oxacillin which he reports is not
anaphylactic.

FAMILY HISTORY:  Sister and brother both had strokes.  Mother
died of bone cancer.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  He is a heavy drinker, quit at age 20.
Previously used marijuana, cocaine, but quit ten years ago.
He has a 15 pack year history of tobacco.  He is married,
does not work.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:  On admission, vital signs: heart rate
90, blood pressure 140/70, respirations 20, oxygen saturation
was 89% on two liters, up to 99% on three liters.  The
patient, generally, is morbidly obese, African American male,
coughing frequently and lying on his side.  Head, eyes, ears,
nose and throat shows pupils were equal, round, and reactive
to light and accommodation, extraocular movements intact,
injected conjunctivae, crusted yellow eyelids with white
sputum visible in posterior of eye.  Neck: large, no
lymphadenopathy appreciated.  Lungs: decreased breath sounds
at the bases with mild expiratory wheezes and bibasilar
rales.  Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm, positive S1, S2,
II/VI systolic murmur at left sternal border, no reproducible
pain.  Abdomen: obese, distended, firm, left lower quadrant
mildly tender, 1+ pitting edema.

Extremities: left ankle with ulceration region and three
areas of erythema.  Ulceration with some green discharge
between the ridges.  Bilateral 2+ lower extremity pitting
edema.  Left upper thigh with increased erythema, increased
warmth and swelling.  Pulses are not palpable.  Skin on feet
is significant for drainage, left greater than right.
Neurologic: the patient is oriented to person and place,
but not to year or date.  The patient does move all
extremities.

ADMISSION LABORATORY DATA:  White blood cell count 19.7,
hematocrit 32.2, platelets 173,000, MCV 84, MCH 27,
neutrophils 79%, bands 4.0, lymphs 13, monos 3.  Sodium 131,
potassium 3.8, chloride 85, bicarbonate 28, BUN 105,
creatinine 5.2, blood sugar 117.  Anion gap 18, CK 132 and
130, CK/MB 2.0 and 2.0, troponin less than 0.3 and less than
0.3.  Urinalysis: yellow, no blood, nitrates, glucose,
ketones, bilirubin, no red blood cells or bacteria.  Blood
cultures times two are pending, urine culture pending.

Chest x-ray shows prominent pulmonary lines and is a limited
study due to body habitus.  Electrocardiogram shows a normal
sinus rhythm at 100 with a right atrial dilation, inverted
T-waves in II and AVF.

ASSESSMENT:  A 46 -year-old with chronic obstructive
pulmonary disease, obstructive sleep apnea, cor pulmonale,
who presents with increased lower extremity pain and swelling
times three days with intermittent chest pain and worsening
cough.

PLAN:
1.  Infectious Disease:  The patient with ulceration on left
lower ankle, gets dressings every other day, green discharge,
consider pseudomonal infection, consider infection with
Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, anaerobes.  The patient has
erythema on thigh and swelling of possible cellulitis.  The
patient is afebrile without fever or chills.  White blood
cell count is elevated at 19.7 with 4 bands.  The patient is
going to receive Ancef and ceftriaxone in the Emergency
Department.

Antibiotics on the floor were changed to Levaquin for gram
positive and Pseudomonas coverage and Flagyl to cover the
anaerobes.  The patient will be re-cultured if a temperature
spike.  The patient will give a sputum culture, wound will be
swabbed for culture.  Dressing changes twice a day with
Bacitracin to the ankle, erythromycin ointment for the eyes
for possible conjunctivitis.

2.  Pulmonary:  The patient will have Dopplers bilaterally to
rule out deep vein thrombosis.  The patient has a cough with
sputum production for one month.  The patient has chronic
obstructive pulmonary disease that requires three liters of
oxygen and obstructive sleep apnea that requires CPAP.  The
patient will received chest physical therapy, Albuterol and
Atrovent nebulizers, CPAP, sputum culture.

3.  Cardiac:  The patient with vague chest pain, lasting
minutes, not radiating, not associated with exertion.  The
patient has inverted T-waves in leads III and AVF, rule out
myocardial infarction with CK/MBs times three and troponin.
The patient given aspirin, sublingual nitroglycerin.  The
patient is preload dependent, so we will avoid medicines that
decrease preload.

4.  Renal:  The patient has chronic renal failure, now with
an acute increase in creatinine, may be prerenal state
secondary to overdiuresis.  The patient is also complaining
that he is concerned with decreased urine output.  The
patient's urine osmolality, creatinine, sodium, urea will be
rechecked.  The patient will get a Foley catheter, strict
intakes and outputs, and weights, will follow his BUN and
creatinine.  Renal dose of Levaquin will be 250 mg po q day,
will hold Lasix for now.

5.  Pain control:  The patient has increased pain in the
lower extremities, so we will give him Percocet and Tylenol.

6.  Dermatology:  We will continue the patient's regimen for
his elephantiasis of his lower extremities, using Nystatin
cream, miconazole lotion.

7.  Hypertension:  Continue hydralazine 100 mg qid, continue
clonidine 0.3 mg q day, Isordil 40 mg tid, hold Diltiazem.
The patient needs decreased afterload, but is preload
dependent.

8.  Mental status:  The patient is disoriented.  We will
follow his mental status to determine if this is his baseline
or if another process is occurring.

HOSPITAL COURSE:
1.  Pulmonology:  During this hospital course, the patient
stabilized with a nonproductive cough.  The patient was
requiring CPAP at night, O2 dependence for his chronic
obstructive pulmonary disease with saturations from 85% on
five liters and 76% on room air during the night of [**2139-9-1**].
The patient was transferred to the Medical Intensive Care
Unit for O2 saturations as low as 70% on five liters.  The
patient noted to be slightly disoriented and tremulous.
Arterial blood gases were sent, noting a pH of 7.2, CO2 of
91, and oxygen of 90.  A chest x-ray was done.  He was given
one dose of Lasix IV 80 mg.  He was also given nitroglycerin
paste and placed on BiPAP.  A repeat arterial blood gas was
taken at the time and was pH of 7.27, CO2 of 70, and an O2 of
39.

At that time the patient became hypoxic and required
ventilatory support.  The patient was then on [**2139-9-2**]
transferred to the Medical Intensive Care Unit while on the
ventilator.  The patient stayed on the ventilator up until
[**2139-9-15**], when at that time due to failure to weaning off the
ventilator, the decision was made by the physicians and
patient as well as patient's wife, that a permanent or
semi-permanent tracheostomy would be performed with a
tracheostomy tube in place.  A tracheostomy tube was placed
and the patient has been on ventilatory support through his
tracheostomy tube, doing well.

The patient, on discharge, was able to be on pressure support
of 20, PEEP of 10, oxygen pressure of 40%, respirations at
10, breathing on his own with tidal volume 700-900 with over
a liter during large breaths.  The patient's arterial blood
gas before discharge with a pH of 7.4, CO2 of 44, oxygen
saturation of 116%.  The patient doing well, voice seems to
be coming back, able to communicate somewhat, able to answer
questions with yes or no by moving his head.  The patient is
much more alert and tolerating breathing on his own overnight
as well, not requiring any mandatory breaths or IMV.

The patient had a bleeding issue when the tracheostomy tube
was placed.  The patient did received DDAVP for uremic
platelets during this increased BUN and creatinine, renal
insufficiency.  The bleeding did stop and the patient is not
bleeding currently from the tracheostomy site.  Of note, the
patient did have oozing and some bleeding from the Quinton
site for his hemodialysis.  That site was changed and a
slight hematoma developed at the site of the new left Quinton
catheter.  The patient currently has an O2 saturation of 100%
on the current ventilator settings that he will be discharged
on.  Pressure support of 20, PEEP of 10, FiO2 of 40%.

2.  Cardiac:  The patient was ruled out for a myocardial
infarction.  The patient has known right heart issues with
tricuspid regurgitation and pulmonary hypertension.  An
electrocardiogram was done which showed, on [**2139-8-31**], mildly
dilated atrium, a mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy
of the left ventricle is normal, overall left ventricular
systolic function is normal.  Septal flattening and
paradoxical septal motion.  Right ventricle is markedly
dilated, severe global right ventricular free wall
hypokinesis, moderate to severe 3+ tricuspid regurgitation,
severe pulmonary artery systolic hypertension.

The patient did have some episodes of hypotension during his
hospital course and requiring a Dopamine IV drip.  The
patient currently has a blood pressure of 125/66.  Dopamine
drip was stopped and the patient's normal cardiac medicines
were restarted, such as hydralazine and clonidine and
Isordil.  The patient's chest x-ray showed possible
congestive heart failure, with a portable chest x-ray
compared to a previous one done on [**2139-8-28**] showing heart
appears to be enlarged, pulmonary vascularity appears
engorged and slightly indistinct, elevation of right
hemidiaphragm.  The patient had a LENI on [**2139-8-30**] which
showed no deep vein thrombosis, but was a limited study.

3.  Infectious Disease:  The patient had a Quinton catheter,
a triple lumen subclavian, and a PICC line, all replaced due
to line infection which started with a low grade temperature
on [**2139-9-9**] and increased white blood cell count.  The
patient was put on vancomycin with dosing levels for renal
insufficiency.  Sensitivities eventually showed the catheter
tips grew Enterococci that were sensitive to ampicillin.  The
patient was changed to ampicillin at this time, renally
dosed.  The patient is presently on day four of a fourteen
day regimen of ampicillin.

The patient was also started on erythromycin ointment for a
conjunctivitis.  Conjunctivitis has since cleared, but
continues to have conjunctival hemorrhage.  The patient did
receive a ten day course of Levaquin for a leg ulcer.  The
patient has been afebrile recently.  The patient's ulcer swab
grew Pseudomonas which was pansensitive.  Blood cultures
recently showed no growth.  Sputum cultures showed sparse
oropharyngeal growth.

4.  Renal status:  He has acute on chronic renal failure,
etiology is unclear.  The patient had a Foley placed.  Urine
output did increase.  The patient receiving three times a
week hemodialysis.  Creatinine on discharge is 3.1, close to
baseline for this patient with a BUN of 90 and a potassium of
4.2.  The patient did receive IV fluids and now is able to
tolerate tube feeds and the patient did receive three days of
total parenteral nutrition while waiting for tube feeds.

5.  Gastrointestinal:  The patient's gastrointestinal
situation has cleared.  The patient was ruled out for an
obstruction with a KUB.  The patient was given po
erythromycin and various bowel regimens to stimulate the
gastrointestinal tract.  The patient had three large bowel
movements over the past three days and is now tolerating tube
feeds and moving his bowels appropriately.

6.  Hematology:  The patient's coagulopathy seems to have
cleared.  The patient's bleeding and oozing at tracheostomy
site and lines have stopped, although there is a small
hematoma at the site of the Quinton catheter.  The patient
was also given vitamin K during these episodes.  The patient
continues to have a slight anemia with a hematocrit of 28.3.
The patient was transfused during his hospital stay with four
units of packed red blood cells.  The patient's ferritin and
iron studies showed that he was consistent with anemia of
chronic disease.  The patient is receiving Epogen three times
a week.

7.  Dermatology:  The patient's dermatological issues are
being covered with ointments applied to the elephantiasis due
to chronic lymphatic obstruction.  The patient receives cloth
wraps for his lower extremities which seem to help with the
lymphatic stasis and elephantiasis.  The patient did receive
a bronchoscopy during his hospital stay for issues of
bleeding from the tracheostomy site.  The patient was found
to have good airways and any blood in the airway was
suctioned and no active bleeding was found.

8.  Neurology:  The patient's neurologic status is improved.
The patient is status post sedation for the intubation.  He
is now clearing.  The patient is able to answer questions, is
attempting to speak with some limited use of his voice.

DISPOSITION:  The patient will be discharged to a facility
that can accommodate his ventilation requirements, most
likely [**Hospital1 **] in [**Hospital1 8**] or Olympus Specialty in
[**Location (un) 38**].  The patient's wife is aware of his situation.
The patient is a full code.  The patient will be discharged

DISCHARGE DIAGNOSES:
1.  Obstructive sleep apnea.
2.  Pulmonary hypertension.
3.  Renal insufficiency.
4.  Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with possible
congestive heart failure.

DISCHARGE STATUS:  Stable, on oxygen at night with the need

ADDENDUM:  Since the last discharge summary, dictated on
[**2139-9-21**], there have been additional events during

1.  Pulmonary:  The patient has been requiring less
ventilator support.  He was weaned down to ventilator
settings of pressure support of 5 and PEEP of 5 with 30%
FiO2, and was doing well on those settings.  Therefore, he
has been allowed to come off the ventilator for trial with
50% tracheostomy mask.  These trials should be no longer than
12 hours during the day, as the patient will begin to retain
carbon dioxide if left off of the ventilator for longer than
that.  He clinically does not become severely tachypneic,
however, in a recent trial, the patient was off of the
ventilator for over 24 hours and arterial blood gases
subsequently showed a pH of 7.15, pCO2 of 75 and pO2 of 60.
He also tolerates a Passe Muir valve well.  He has
significant secretions but he is able to clear them on his
own and suction them on his own with the Yankauer suction.
His oxygen saturations on the ventilator range from 93% to
98% and, when off the ventilator, range from the upper 80s to
low 90s.  The most recent ventilator settings which the
patient was rested on were a C-PAP and pressure support of 10
with 5 of PEEP at an FiO2 of 0.5.

2.  Cardiovascular:  The patient is hemodynamically stable
and continues on Isordil, hydralazine and clonidine for blood
pressure control.  At the time of discharge, he is becoming
more hypertensive, with blood pressures up to 170 systolic.
If further blood pressure control is necessary, a calcium
channel blocker should be considered to be added to the
regimen, as this is what the patient was on previously as an
outpatient, and a beta blocker was tried while admitted at
[**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 3867**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **] and resulted in the
patient with a subjective feeling of shortness of breath.

3.  Infectious disease:  The patient, as stated in the
previous discharge summary, had been found to have
Enterococcal bacteremia, for which he was on ampicillin twice
a day.  He subsequently grew Enterococcus out of both new
line and a peripheral site.  He had a transthoracic
echocardiogram which revealed no evidence of endocarditis.
This was discussed with cardiology and infectious disease as
to whether the patient required a transesophageal
echocardiogram in order to definitively rule out
endocarditis.  It was decided that the patient had adequate
windows on the transthoracic echocardiogram and, as long as
subsequent blood cultures remained negative, it could
concluded that the patient did not have endocarditis.
Therefore, the patient's ampicillin dose was increased to 1
gram every six hours and surveillance blood cultures were
drawn repeatedly after the increased ampicillin dose.  All of
those cultures remained negative and the patient is to
receive his last dose of ampicillin at 6:00 p.m. on the day
of discharge.

The patient also grew Stenotrophomonas, which was drawn off
of his arterial line.  This line was pulled and he was
treated with Bactrim for a ten day course, and no further
blood cultures have grown Stenotrophomonas.  Finally, the
patient developed a vesicular rash on his left chest in a
dermatomal distribution around to his back, and dermatology
was consulted for this.  It was felt to be herpes zoster,
which was confirmed by culture.  He is currently on day six
of a ten day course with acyclovir, renally dosed, in order
to treat this.

4.  Renal:  The patient continues on hemodialysis three times
a week, on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays.  He had a
Perm-A-Cath placed on the right on [**2139-10-2**] after all
blood cultures had been negative from Enterococcus.  His
baseline creatinine is in the 3s on hemodialysis.  He does
not have problems with hyperkalemia.

5.  Gastrointestinal:  The patient suffered an upper
gastrointestinal bleed on [**2139-9-30**].  On that day, he
was incontinence of loose black/brown stool overnight, which
were occult blood positive.  Nasogastric lavage was
performed, which was occult blood positive.  His hematocrit
went from 24.8 down to 21.4 with the bleed.  Gastroenterology
was consulted and an upper endoscopy was performed, which
found grade II esophagitis in the lower third of the
esophagus, an ulcer in the distal body of the stomach,
erythema, erosion and friability in the antrum, fundus and
cardia compatible with gastritis, and erythema, friability
and erosion in the duodenum compatible with duodenitis.  The
patient was eventually transfused with eight units of packed
red blood cells and he was placed on increased Protonix of 40
mg twice a day for three days, and he was evaluated for
Helicobacter pylori, which came back negative.  At the time
of discharge, the patient is back on a Protonix dose of 40 mg
daily and he is tolerating orals of soft solids without any
further evidence of bleeding.

6.  Hematology:  The patient's hematocrit has been stable in
the upper 20s since receiving his transfusion.  He continues
to receive Epogen three times per week as well.

7.  Dermatology:  Again, the patient was found to have herpes
zoster, for which he is currently in the middle of a ten day
course of acyclovir.  He also receives Domeboro solution
soaks to the zoster lesions twice a day for pruritus.  His
elephantiasis is improving on the Estar gel and the Hibiclens
soaks, and the Lotrimin cream, the doses of which are
outlined in the medication section of the discharge summary.

8.  Neurology:  The patient has left upper extremity weakness
which continues.  He was evaluated by neurology for this, and
it is felt that the patient most likely has nerve compression
secondary to a hematoma which formed after his tracheostomy
was placed.  The hematoma is slowly resolving.  The patient
could not be adequately imaged in order to evaluate this more
thoroughly due to his size.  Some plain films of the neck
were attempted to rule out any bony involvement which could
be contributing to compression, however, they also were of
suboptimal quality because of the patient's size.  The
recommendation of the neurology team at the time of discharge
is that the patient should receive an EMG one month after
discharge in order to assess ultimate prognosis.  He also can
follow up in the [**Doctor First Name **]-[**Country **] neurology clinic after the EMG
is performed.  The telephone number is [**Telephone/Fax (1) 44**].  In
addition, once the patient is able to tolerate it, if
possible, he should get a neck and brachial plexus CT scan in
a facility which can accommodate weights greater than 350
pounds.  Finally, his pain should continue to be adequately
treated.  At the time of discharge, he is receiving Tylenol
#3 as needed.

Chief Complaint:

Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
I+D perirectal abscess (6/23+[**6-10**]), left open

History of Present Illness:
78 yo male with multiple medical problems admitted on [**6-5**] for
fever, perirectal abscess, ARF. He lives alone and had
apparently been experiencing pain in rectum due to
"folliculitis" for several weeks. He is diabetic and had very
poor PO intake prior to admission. He was dehydrated, confused,
febrile and in pain when he was admitted to the medicine service
from the emergency department.

Past Medical History:
* diabetes type 2
* hypercholesterolemia
* hypertension
* GERD
* PVD
* degenerative joint disease
* LLE atherectomy
* CCY
* pancreatitis

Social History:
lives at home alone.  cooks for himself.  quit smoking for 48
years in [**2154**].  used to drink alcohol but has not for several
years.

Family History:
non-contributory

Physical Exam:
VITALS  (on discharge)97.8  135/42  60  18 97%3L
GEN: pleasant, NAD,well-nourished
HEENT: PERRL, EOMI, sclera anicteric, no conjuctival injection,
mucous membranes dry, no lymphadenopathy, neck supple, full ROM,
neg JVD, no carotid bruits
[**Last Name (un) **]: very poor air movement bl, exp wheeze.
COR: RRR, S1 and S2 wnl, no murmurs/rubs/gallops
ABD: non-distended with positive bowel sounds, non-tender,no
guarding, no rebound or masses
Rectum: Wound is open, clean and dry. Minimal skin induration,
minimal tenderness. No discharge or odor.
EXT: no cyanosis, clubbing, edema


Pertinent Results:
Cardiac enzymes negative several times
Albumin low (2.5)
[**6-22**]: WBC 9.5, HCT 31.1
[**2170-6-22**] UreaN-9 Creat-0.9 Na-139 K-4.2 Cl-108 HCO3-24 AnGap-11
